channel.title: RSCD Database Structure
channel.description:
If you were to scrap RSCD's database structure and re-do it, what would you change?
So far, I'm going to include the experience and current stats fields within the players table as they're all called at the same time so it seems stupid to have multiple joins for no reason. There's an identical amount of rows in each table anyway.
Another thing is instead of linking the items/friends to the player by the username hash we're going to use the unique increment ID of the players table as an int will always be quicker than a varchar or bigint.

item.title: RSCD Database Structure
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

You can still add yourself to your own friends list on the official RSC. Just change your display name a first and a second time. When you changed it your second time, you can add the name of your first change to your friends list. Then you will see yourself on there.

I also used my friends list or ignore list as a notebook earlier. On one of my accounts, I got the creation date written using my friends list or ignore list. It says around 2003 or 2004, so surely back then it worked.

Further on, currently my friends list got weird usernames added. It looks like the usernames hash with a “#” character in front of them. I believe it represents accounts that has been removed for some unknown reasons.

More on-topic: Read up on database normalization. For instance “3NF” or “BCNF” etc.

Read full topic

item.title: RSCD Database Structure
item.dc:creator: @Kryptix Kryptix
item.description:
@Kryptix wrote:

RSCShadow:

So on every login, it’s going to have to go through about 5-100 rows matching those IDs to usernames from the player table?

Eh, no… Instead of selecting all items by their username hash it will instead be by their unique players ID as it’s quicker. I might also put all bank and inventory items in one table as there’s one bank account per player.

RSCShadow:

Also in RSCD (and RSC, mind you), you could add people that didn’t actually exist as well.

If you login RSC and try to add a random name it will say that the player can’t be found. I think it passes the request off to the login server and it handles it from there.

I know it’s unlikely but a player could make 100 characters adding 200 friends and 200 ignores on each which in turn makes 40,000 unneeded database entries. There’s something like 4 million friend entries on RSCE at the moment and the query time is slowing down due to it so if I can figure out a way to accept or decline their friend request I’ll do so I think.

There’s also no filtering with PM’s, anyone could make a bot that logs into the crowded place of Edgeville and auto-PM every player that comes into view as quickly as possible flooding their screen. As PM’s were also handled by the login server on RSC I do think there’s a lot of stuff being handled that we’re not aware of.

gawdz666:

The entire db structure is pure shit. I would optimize it and not have so many fucking tables of such pointless shit.

Could you give any specific examples?

Read full topic

item.title: RSCD Database Structure
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

Another thing is instead of linking the items/friends to the player by the username hash we're going to use the unique increment ID of the players table as an int will always be quicker than a varchar or bigint.
So on every login, it's going to have to go through about 5-100 rows matching those IDs to usernames from the player table? Also in RSCD (and RSC, mind you), you could add people that didn't actually exist as well.

Read full topic
